My journey at EY!!

Hearing about Anna‚Äôs sudden and tragic passing left me feeling deeply saddened. It‚Äôs heartbreaking to think of the immense grief and irreparable loss her family and friends must be experiencing. My deepest condolences to the family and friends.

Recently, while reading various posts on LinkedIn about people's experiences at Big4 firms, I found myself reflecting on my own 8.5-year journey at EY‚Äîa path that, in many ways, feels unique.

My time at EY was filled with moments of gratitude, empathy, and respect, and it shaped me profoundly, both personally and professionally. After 8.5 years of navigating the inevitable ups and downs, I recently made the decision to resign, feeling it was the right time to explore a different career path. It wasn‚Äôt an easy decision, but it came after a period of immense learning, growth, and resilience.

One of the standout features of my time at EY was the emphasis on empathy, which I experienced firsthand from my leaders‚Äîpartners, directors, senior managers, and managers alike. During difficult times, such as when I was unwell or when my parents underwent surgeries, I was never burdened by work demands. Instead, I was met with genuine concern for my well-being and given the space to focus on my family. This kind of support, which I believe is sometimes overlooked in broad-brush discussions about corporate culture, was a defining part of my experience. It‚Äôs something I‚Äôve made a point to carry forward in my own approach to leadership.

Of course, like many others, I had my share of long nights at work. I can still remember coming home at 4 a.m., but even during the busiest times, I always tried to listen to my body and maintain a balance. I learned to prioritize my health‚Äîthrough regular exercise and eating well‚Äîeven when circumstances made it challenging.

Here are a few key lessons I‚Äôve taken away from my time at EY:
1. Empathy is key: True leadership involves creating a culture of empathy, openness, and respect.

2. Take time for yourself: Listen to your body and mind. Don‚Äôt hesitate to take a break when you need it, and don‚Äôt underestimate the value of rest.

3. Prioritize your health: No matter how intense work gets, make time for physical activity. I committed to working out at least four times a week.

4. Healthy choices are within reach: Even during late nights at the office, you can choose to nourish your body with healthy options. While you might not always control your hours, you can control how you fuel yourself.

5. Avoid generalizations: Not all managers or teams at Big4 firms are the same. Each person comes with their own unique goals, perspectives, and leadership styles. It‚Äôs important to appreciate this diversity rather than generalizing the culture.

So, while I understand the experiences shared in many posts, I feel it's important to acknowledge that there are different stories‚Äîmine being one of them.

Hello everyone,

Introducing MeteorDash, an engaging web-based game developed with Next.js. In this game, your hand movements control the action based on how you tilt your hand. The game pauses when hands are not detected and resumes when both hands are back in view.

I'd love for you to try it out and welcome any suggestions for improvement in my project.

Check it out here:
Explore the code here:

Note:
1. Provide camera access to play the game.
2. Close the tab to completely end the game.
